The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Pour soulager les Bébés
div.p: Ah! les angoisses des longues nuits de souf-france et d'insomnie, quand leurs premieres dents cherchent a percer! Mamans, il est de votre devoir, aussi bien pour vous que pour vos enfants, de mettre fin a ces tortures en employant de suite l'Emulsion Scott.
Car, grace a l'Emulsion Scott, les terribles accidents de la dentitio ne sont plus a craindre.
L'Emulsion Scott
Supprime rapidement et completement la souffrance et, tout en meme temps,fortifie le bebe qui, alors, traverse la crise dentaire sans le moindre malaise.
Autre avantage
Les enfants aiment l'Emulsion Scott et la digerent avec une etonnante facilite.
En vente chez tous pharmaciens et droguistes.

div.p: A WEEKLY HALF-HOLIDAY

An excellent suggestion was recently made to us by ore of the leading tradesmen of the city, to the effect that daring the summer months, when little business is done owing to the heat, especially in the after part of the day, shops should be closed at noon one day every week. Not only would the shop it assistants benefit by the half holiday, but in many instances the principals themselves would be glad of the weekly relaxation, which, in our opinion, could be arranged with little or no difficulty if those interested in the mattsr would take up the question and urge it opon the leading employers. Already the saturday half holiday is enjoyed by the clerks in many offices, and the extension of the boon to the retail trade should be easily brought about There is all the more reason for the adoption of some such measure, inasmuch as there is no such thing as a weekly day of rest for very many shop assistants, who from morning to night, Sundays and holidays included, have to attend to their daily round of duties

It is satisfactory to note that the Sunday closing of shops in Egypt is making steady progress. Not many years ago, when an English firm then commencing basinets in Egypt expressed its intention of remaining closed from Saturday to Monday, the leading partner was told that he would find it impossible to succeed without opening as usual on Sunday. But he would not give way and to-day his firm is one doing a very extensive business both here and in Cairo ; and his example has been followed very generally among the leading tradesmen of both towns. The great exception to what would otherwise be the general rule is to be found in the provision trade, and it is somewhat surprising to find that no serious effort is made to obtain the closing of these establishments on Sunday. It would be interesting to hear what steps are being taken by the Société des Employés in this direction, though it is somewhat late in the day for anybody to bring forward arguments in favour of the absolute necessity of one day’s rest in seven. If the human machine it to be kept in perfect working order; the extension of Sunday closing during the last few years and the impossibility of reverting to seven days' work per week when the weekly rest day has been established, affording ample proof that the system has not been found wanting.

We look forward with some degree of confidence to action being taken in favour of a weekly half-holiday in the retail trade, and feel sure that even if in the first instance it is only arranged for during the summer, it will soon become an all-the-year-round institution and perhaps pave the way for the still greatest boon of a weekly rest-day for those who do not, at present enjoy this very necessary relaxation from their daily labours.

div.head: THE MURDER OF MR. GLANVILLE AT MAAGHIL
div.p: Mr. Lonsdale asked the Secretary of Foreign in the House of Commons last week whether he had received information of the murder of several British subjects recently in the villages of Baghdad and Basra

Sir E. Grey: His Majesty’s Government have received information of the murder of one British subject, Mr. Glanville, at Maaghil and his Majesty’s Ambassador at Constantinople giving every attention to the matter. A special commission is being dispatched by the Ottoman Government to convert such measures as are required for the maintenance of order.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Quarantine.
Quarantine restrictions as against plague arrivals from Iodia are no longer supplied in Egyptian ports.
Bathing Fatality.
A native, aged 20, was drowned yesterday in the Mahmoudieh Canal where he was swimming. The body was recovered and sent to hospital for a post-mortem examination.
The Mahroussa
H.H. the Khedive's yacht, the Mahroussa left the timber wharf at Yorkhill and went up to the crane at Finnieston on the Clyde last week, to receive the remainder of her turbine machinery.
Fatal Railway Accident

Three days ago, a syrian employé at the Port Said railway station was attempting to mount a train which was actually starting from the station, when he slipped and fell on the rails, receiving serious injuries to which he succumbed shortly afterwards in hospital.
The Plague

Yeterday's plague bulletin records two cases at Alexandria, one of whichwas fatal. A native girl was admitted to hospital and a native porter was found dead athis house in the Labbane kism. To-day's bulletin records another case at Alexandria, a native women living at Kom-el-Shougafah being admitted to hospital.
Bank of Egypt Interim Dividend.

The interim dividend at the rate of 8 percent per annum announced by the Bank of Egypt forthe half-year that ended the 30th ult. is at the same rate as for the corresponding period. For the whole of 1905 18 percent was distributed, following 16 percent for 1905, 14 percent for 1903, 13 percent for 1902, and 12 percent for 1901.
San Stefano Casino.

The Bracale Orchestra's concerts are becoming more and more interesting and popular. Yesterday a large audience listened to the matinée classique and among other items the prelude of Lohengrin and Goldmark's Ouverture were [erfectly executed and much applauded. The afternoon concert with the vocal parts drew together more than four thousand people on the terrace. The management of the casino are preparing a treat for the Fourteenth July, when there will be a Venetian fête, and the Tiro Blanc (pari mutuel) will be opened.
St. Catherine's College

The examinations of students for the baccalauréat Français at the above college took place last week, and the extraordinarily good results are highly creditable to the institution. Out of the eighteen candidates presented, sixteen passel. The three candidates for mathematics were admitted with honours. These were messrs. Antoine Ackaouy, Mario Monferrato, and Alexandre Dibo. The candidates who were admitted in the first part were messrs. Byron Dellaporta, E. Fiteni, Antoine Kahls, Selim Marcos (honorable mention), Alexandre Michaca, Benoit Nahmias, JeanSanti(honorable mention) Nelson Schranz and Antoine Zogheb (honorable mention). We congratulae the new Lauréats on their success, as alsothe professors of the college.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chambar of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free ofcharge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Addrss, Secretary, British Camber of Conmmerce, Alexandria. (advt,)
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL

At its last meeting the council of ministers decided that Boutros Pasha Ghali, Mohamed Pasha Abani, and Lord Edward Cecil should act as Minister of the Interior, Minister of Finance, and Financial Adviser respectively during the absence of Mustapha Pacha Fehmy, Mazloum Pasha and Sir Vincent Corbett.

The Earl and Countess of Cromer arrived in London last week in the P & O. steaer Persia. At Plymouth Lord Cromer received a telegram informing him that his name was at the head of the Birthday Honours List, the intimation that he had entered the charmed circle of the Order of Merti appearing to afford him the great pleasure. Lady Cromer, who suffered from an attack of measles during the voyage, has now recovered.

The "Vossische Zeitung" announces that Professor Schwally, of Giessen University, the well-known orientalist, has accepted the offer of the arabic chair in the Mohamedan University at Aligardb, in India.

div.head: AFTER DENISHAWAI MORE TROOPS WANTED ARTICLE BY MR. DICEY. (Gazette's special service. London, Monday, July 9.
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., in an article the "Daily Telegraph," says that the latent antagonism between administrators and the administrated in egypt is, in his opinion, not likely to become active under present conditions to such an extent as to endangerthe tenure of our highway to India. The Tribunal, composed of native and English judges, which was constituted by the decree of 1895, has dealt out summary and just punishment to the authors of the Denishwai outrage.

Mr. Dicey is inclined to think that the prompt and stern judgement passed on the ringleaders will tend to keep things quiet. Any mitigation of the well-deserved punishment, would be ascribed, not to humanity, but to fear. We must largely increase our forces both in the Delta and the Sudan, and make it manifest that any outrage of this kind will be punished with equal severity.
MORE QUESTIONS IN PARLIAMENT
Sir Edward Grey was further questioned in the House of Commons last week with reference to the Denishwai executions.

Mr. Reddy asked whether he was aware that whilst one of the Egyptian natives was being hanged at Denishwai, on June 28, two others were flogged within view of the gallows; that a large multitude, including women, were looking on; and that the flogging caused horrible cries; and whether the sentences were carried out under the supervision of Captain Machell, adviser to the Egyptian Minister of the Interior.
Several other Hon. Members had put down questions on the same subject.

Sir E. Grey: In consequence of the statements which have appeared in the Press, I have asked for a full report of how these sentences were carried out with special reference to the points raised in this and other questions. Meanwhile I cannot say who is primarily responsible for the actual carrying out of the sentences.
Mr. Dillon: May we tke that as an answer to all the questions on the paper? If so, when will the right hon. gentleman be in a position to answer those questions.
Sir E. Grey: I have, as a matter of fact, prepared an answer to ever question, but really the reply i have given applies to all of them.
Mr. Reddy: Does the right hon. gentleman deesire to cloak it? (cries of "order")
Mr. Myer: Is the report in the newspapers substantially true?

Sir E. Grey: On this particular point i have asked for a full report of all the circumstances.(ministerial cheers.) I assume there can be only one impression produced by the details as they appeared in the newspapers, and i think it most desirable that instead of giving information piecmeal we should have a full report. (Hear, hear.) when that report is received I shall, of course, be prepared to lay it on the table.
Mr. Macneill: Will the right hon. gentleman direct the full report to be cabled?
Sir E. Grey: No, sir. the number of points raised inconnection with both sentences and trial make it absolutley necessary that it should be considered a report. (Hear, hear)
Mr. Pickersgill: Will the right hon. gentleman be in possesion of that report before the Foreign Office vote is taken?
Sir E.Grey: I do not think it is possible that the report can be received by Thursday.

Mr. Dillon: Then will the right hon gentleman consider the desirability of postponing the vote, or get the report sent by cable? Would it not be very unfair to deny the House the only opportunity it will have of considering the report this session?

Sir E. Grey: I recognise the importance of the matter, but there are other questions which should also be considered not connected with it. (Hear, hear.) My one object is to give the House the fullest inforation, and not to minimise the matter in any way. when I am in possession of the report, no doubt an oppurtunity will be found for its discussion.
Sir E. Grey: The sentences were ordered to be carried out in public, and when I have recieved the full report the question of whether such executions should take place in public will be considered.
Mr. Dillon: May I ask whether any official attempt has been made to induce any of the London Press to abstain from publishing any of the details of these cases?
Sir E. Grey: I am not aware of any attempt, official or otherwise, to influence that Press in any way.

Mr. C. Wason asked the prime minister, if in view of the demoralising effect of public executions and floggings, and their long abandonment in the United Kingdom,he would order their discontinuance in all countries directly on indirecty under the flag of the British Empire.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman: I will consult my colleagues as to the extent, which i believe to be very limited, to wish public executions take place, and consider whether any and what steps should be taken.

div.head: Sir E. Grey's Speech. Comments of Native Press.
div.p: Commenting on Sir Edward Grey's speech in the House of Commons on Friday, "Al-Moayad" says:--"Lord Cromer was present when Sir Edward Grey delivered his sensatinal speech à propos of the Denishwai sentence; and we may infer that the British Diplomatic Agent was the real speaker, the latter being only inspired by him to deliver so alarming a speech before the british Parliament. We understand from that apeech that Lord Cromer, in the person of Sir E. Grey, has been fearing that an inquiry into the Denishwai affair would probably be required by Parliament and that such an inquiry, if seriously held, would show who were really responsible for the affair and would reveal the secret of the case. That is why he requested Parliament not to pass a hasty judgement in the matter. Lord Cromer, who knows that members of Parliament are unaware of Egyptian customs and havits of mind, could not find anything better than the plea of religious fanaticism to make the more sagacious members cease to press for a reply to their just demands. Religious fanaticism has shown itself this year, according to Lord Cromer, not only in Egypt byt also in all the northern party of Africa. He did not forget to add that this fanaticism has been directed against all Europeans in Egypt alike. Now, Religious fanaticism is sort of a goblin- a mumbo jumbo- to the British officials here; they, it apprears, become frightened of its effects and remain silent. Sir Edward Grey then emphasized his speech declaring that Parliament should by no means weaken or destroy the Egyptian Government's authority, the suppression of which will lead to serious reukts. It is by this unjust and unfair policy that Egypt is governed. No other voice exceot that of the absolute Governor of Egypt can ever be heard in England. Lord Cromer said nothing about the Denishwai incidentin Parliament, but, in the person of Sir E. Grey, requested the members no to deal with this question, which was a "result of religious fanaticism." Had the noble Lord asked himself whether the fanaticism was really in existence or not he would have believed the latter as he has experience in the Egyptian qualities and circumstances. Hearing such a debate to have taken place in the British Parliament we have to contradict every word pronounced regarding the fanatisicm of the Egyptians. Lord Cromer acts to preserve his absolutism in Egypt from any superior authority such as that of Parliament, which in discussing such matters considers nobody to be above justice. The Egyptians, consequesntly, cannot maintain any safeguards for their national future unless hey set their matters directly before Parliament, whih should know how matters stand in Egypt from a native source. This was what we declared several years ago when we visited London and shook hands with some of the members of Parliament.

Sheikh Ali Youssef, it will be remembered, paid a visit to London a few years ago. A banquet organised by Mr. Benjamin Mosely, at which a number of journalists ad several members of Parliament were present,was given in his honour.

"Al Lewa" says:-- How does the British Minister know that religious fanaticism exists in Egypt, and that itis dangerous? Did he derive this conclusion from the Denishwai people, who are all "learned and of a high class," or from their attacks against the British troops in their camp? There is no reason why they should put everything down in Egypt to religious fanaticism. If the British officials like to defend their policy in Egypt they will be acting most unreasonably, imputing criminality and fanaticism to all the Egyptians, and could surely find some other arguments to defend that policy. It is curious to hear that the Europenas in Egypt are in danger; and we should like to know what are the other meausures which the British Government would take in Egypt beyond those already taken by the occupation. We call upon the Regent to contradict against the Egyptians in the British Parliament, as we know the effects of such serious suspicions, and to what result the suspicions of Sir E. Grey are likely to lead.

The comments made by "aL-Minbar" are on the same lines as those of "AL-Moayad." Says out new contempoary: Lord Cromer has delivered a speech in the person of Sir E Grey in Parliament, and he only went to the House to hear and see what effects his arguments would produce upon the members.

After mentioning the "Daily Telegraph's" statement regarding the Egyptians, their fanaticism, and attachment to the Turkish Government, "AL-Minbar" says: Our only Fault is to dare to criticise British policy in Egypt and sympathise with the Ottoman Government owing to its suzerainty ovr Egypt.

div.head: ANOTHER ASSAULT ON BRITISH SOLDIER ATTACKED AT MUSTAPHA.
div.p: An Attack on a soldier is reported from Sidi Gaber, where a drunken Arab caught a soldier of the 2nd Royal Dublin Fusiliers by the collar, throwing him down. The soldier recovered himself and knocked his assailant down and then seeing two other arabs coming up retired to barracks, where he reported the incident. The police are enquring into the matter.
Pte. O'Brien, of the Dublin Fusiliers, who was injured in an attack made on him by robbers at Mex on Monday last, is doing well.
DEMENTIS.
We are authorised to state that the account of an alleged interview with Major Pine Coffin published by "Al Zahir" on the authority ofone of its reporters, is incorrect.
Major Pine Coffin is reported is reported to have stated that he did not believe one of the four condemned men to be guilty. No such statement was made.

The statement published by various papers that Murad Effendi, the dismissed police officer of the Shohada post, has died of an apoplectic fit caused by cagrin at his dismissal, is alsoincorrect Murad Efendi is now in Alexandria.
SHOULD FLOGGING BE REINTRODUCED?

In the course of an interview with Ismail Pasha Abaya, of the Legislative Council, a representative of "Al-Moayad" asked his excellency whether he approved of the suggestion of some newspapers, including the "EGytptian Gazette," that the Governmnet should reintroduce flogging as a punishment for a certin class of criminals in Egypt The Pasha is said to have replied as follows: "I had not read this news in the papers before you told me ofit. As to be flogging being more useful and effective that imprisonment, that it quite unreasonable, and i do not think that anyone, possesing feelings and reason, would weigh that present circumstances of our country and yet require the Government to make use of the ship as means of punishment."
From the Pasha's words, remaks the writer, I gather that if the suggested reintroduction of flogging is brought before the liegislative council for discussion that project will meet with disapproval.
GOVERNMENT EMPLOYES

Lord Edward Cecil, under-secratary of state atthe ministry of finance, has reutned to Cairo on the expiration of his leave of absence, and will actas Financial Advisor in the absence of Sir Vincent Corbett. The Committee for the improvement of the condition of state employes will now, under the presidency of Lord Edward Cecil consider the lot of the upper grade of officials.
SUNNIS AND SHIITES
Advices from Teheran report that recently a score of Persian Mullahs who were propagating Pan-Islamism on behalf of the Sultan sought refuge in the Ottoman Embassy.
At Shiraz 500 persians sought the protection of the British Consulate. It has not transpired what the reason for their action is, but it is probably due to heresy from the Shiite faith.
EGYPT AND LEVANT STEAMSHIP COMPANY
The statutory general meeting of the shareholders of the Egypt and Levant Steamship Company, Limted, will be held at 8, Leadenhall Street, London, on Monday, 16th inst.

According to the directors' report, the total number of shares issued is 159,000, all of which have been allotted, and of which shares there are (1) 139,000 ordinary shares of 1 each, upon which 2s. was payable on application, 3s on allotment and the balance of 15s by instalments of 5s and 10s on the 15th June 1906, and the 15th July 1906 respectively, and (2) 20,000 Deferred shares of 1s each for which cash has been received. The Total amount of cash received by the company is respect of the shares issued is 62,515 14s., and the following payments have been made of capital account:--Preliminary expenses, 563 17s 4d.; new boats, 12,000 0s 0d; paid to vendors on account of purchase price, 12,300 os od; total 24,863 17s 4d.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS
The Messageries S.S. Portugal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here tomorrow.

div.head: THE LEVANT SQUADRON RUMOURS OF RE-ESTABLISHMENT.
div.p: It is rumoured at Gibraltat that the former Levante quadrom is to be re-established. Four Atlantic ships are to be attached to Malta, and six ships to remain in Malta and six ships to remain in Malta and six ships to cruise in the Levant during the winter months. The reason given for the increase is thay since cruising was discontinued in Eastern waters numerous difficulties have arisen in Egypt and Turkey. The Mediterranean Fleet will probably remain at Gibraltar three weeks after the manoeuvres, and then, calling at Malta, will proceed to the Atlantic, and from there to the East.
DR. ANDREWS' INVESTAGATIONS IN THE FAYOUM.

The interesting results obtained by Dr. C. W. Andrews in his investigations of the fossil mammalia of the classical region of the Fayoum, have (the "Globe" states) been published in the form of a descriptive catalogue by the trustees of the British Museum. The strata from which the remains have been obtained are of middle and upper Eocene age, and are situated to the north of that ancient irrigation reservoir knownas Lake Moeris. The more recent of these beds show indications of having been deposited nearer the land mass, and the coast line advanced northwards as time passed on

One of the most interesting mammalian forms described is a four-toed ungulate, with remarkably massive and powerful horns. Near the place where its bones were disinterred from the rocks stands themount representing the site of Arsinoe, otherwise Crocodilopolio where the sacred crocodile kept in Lake Moeris was worshipped. Hence Dr. Andrews has appropriately named this strange creature Arsinoitherium, that is, the beast of Arsinoe. LakeMoeris, again, has provided a name for Moeritherium, interesting as the earliest and most generalised representative of the Probosoidian, or Elephant, order. Africa, which is one of the two regions where the elephants now occur, was thus probably the place of origin of the order.

Another interesting Fayoum species is the Megalohyrax, or Giant Hyrax. This would appear to be the first fossil representative of that curious modern animal, the Hyrax. There are some thirteen species of these little animals, though some authorities consider many of them to be mere varieties.Showing in their structure and habits affiaities with such diverse forms as the hare, rhinoceros, hippopotamus, and sloth their classifcation has been somewhat of a difficulty to zoologists. Regarded by some as rodents, they were casted by cuvier with his Pachyderms. Hax'ey cute the Gordian knot of their relationship by making them a separate order. With the exception of the Syrian Hyrax, probably the "Cony" of scripture, the Hyracoidea are confined to Africa.

It is interesting thus to find that Africa, the present home of the Hyrax, was also the place of origin of the family, and that it was in Eocene times represented by omparatively giganticspecies. Dr. Andres considers that the new facts brought to light by his researches support the theory of a former land connection between Africa and South America. This existed perhaps in Jurassic times, and continued up to tertiary.
JEWISH HISTORICAL SOCIETY

The annual conference of the Union of Jewsish Literary Societies held in London was brought to a close last week with a meeting held in the Physics Theatre of University College, under the auspices of the Jewish Historical Society. The chariman, Dr. H. Gollancz, referred to the fact that the society now had its headquarters in that building, and that the Mocatta library, about to be opened, was being taken over by the authorities of the college. He had hoped that in return for the hospitality afforder to the Jewish Historical Society, those students who engaged in the stufy of Hebrew and Orientallanguages at the Universitywould dervice material assistance from the memorial library now being established.

The proceedings took the form of a series of lectures by Sir Isidore Spielmann, Mr. Israel Abrahams, and the Rev. S. Levy. The firstnamed gave a detailed history of the events which led up to the Whitehall Conference in 1655, which resulted in the Readmission of the Jews into England through the strenuous efforts of Menasseh ben Israel. Mr. Abrahams gave and interesting description of the "crafwford" Hagadah, the book recited in all Jewish households on the first eve of Passover, narrating the story of the miraculous deliverance from Egyptian bondage. A perfect series of lantern slides, taken from photographs by Mr. Frank Haes, were requisitioned to illustrate the lecture, which was humorously delivered by Mr. Abrahams.

Mr. Levy explained a number of portraits shown on the screen, giving details of some of the leading figures at the Whitehall conference, principal among them being SirJohn Glynee, the representative of law, and Major General Lambert, one of the three members who advocated the readission of the Jews without any restrictions whatever. Simon de Montfort's Leicester Charter, forbidding Jews to reside in the city of Leicester, was the concluding paper of the evening's programme.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by out correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.
MR. DILLON AND DENISHWAI
We have received the following letter from a well-known member of a Roman Catholic Mission:

Dear Mr. Editor,-- With your kind permission i should willingly try to justify Mr. Dillon's conduct in the House of Commons relative to the Denishwai affair. I dont think it fair to say he has been unruly. I dont think it right to have it asserted he has been governed by malicious impulses.

Let us consider the facts. Unfortunately I havent a copy of his first question, but, if my memory does not fail me, they were about the trial by special court. He desired to know if the officers were on duty, and furthermore if they were in uniform; and Sir. E. Grey, being unable to answer, graciously promised to take note of the implicit remark conveyed through the questions. Now, a polite answer generally supposes a correct question, and the Secretary for Foreign Affairs had, himself, no difficulty in admitting the soundness of Mr. Dillon's view. And surely they were not both unruly, or did Sir E. Grey feel a little of the impulse?

His more recent questions have been asked with the same apparent calm and dignity, and answered as fully as possible, a fact that proves their reasonableness has been approved of. Had the justice of an English Court; were they in no wise related? If so, was it not the interest of the English nation to see things done thoroughly and rightly? What is unruly in asking were the pigeons tame or wild, in asking had the officers permission to shoot, in ascertaining were the Arabs provoked before they attacked? What is unruly in all the rest? Let the judges of the Special Court give the answer: they have inquired into all these things with a greater animus, i hope, than even Mr. Dillon himself has manifested. Mr. Dillon, in my opinion, has acted through no impulse whatsoever but his conduct is stamped with honour. I have heard most repectable Englishmen in Egypt say, with whom he is intimately acquainted, that Mr. Dillon is the most perfect gentlemen they have ever met with. It is not right then to slander him, even here in this out-of-the-way, half-civilised country: Cui honor, honor.

I have nothing to say for the followers of Mr. Dillon. He has none: he is but himself the follower of an able and enlightened man who is an honour and an ornament to the British Parliament. The party to which he belongs is meant undoubtedly "but of course it is known to all Britishers in this country" that they, the members of that party, disturb and dirty the limpid waters of every policy, even when these waters quietly flow uphill.

These questions are sure, in fact, to do more good than harm. They plainly show to Egyptians and others that justice and fairplay have their representatives in the imperial parliament, and that nobody shall be trodden under foot with impunityor wihtout the stigma of abhorrence. And no man is more entitled to rank among these than Mr. Dillon, who has known how to uphold a just cause and suffer for it. I trust, then, that "anglo-Egyptian" will not think it amiss on my part for having crossed swords with him over the honour and respect due to Mr. John Dillon.

Now, one might think i am against the severity of the Denishwai verdict. Not in the least. In the words of and English paper, it was a regrettable and unhappy necessity. The criminals acted with cowardice and brutality, and if they have met with a rigorous treatment, they have, in the full senseof the word, been cruel and merciless. And those who try to polliate their conduct do so, I am afriad, throughunruly sympathy or foul jealousy.
But this has nothing to do with a justice-loving representative a justice loving people. Fairplay
Turkish Coal
To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,--In reply to "Coal Merchant," I gave ten shillings as the maximum cost of the coal, as I am not sure what the latest figure is C.I.F. the coal is sold in Constantinople, 180 miles away, at 16s. the ton, but isnot much in evidence in view of the opposition of a number of coal-agents who represent English collieries and who allege that the Herackes coal contains too much sulphur to make it of use to oceangoing steamers. This is perhaps true of some refuse stuff that is brought down, but where the coal has properlu washed and screened excellent results are obtained, to the satisfaction of all. In fact I know of several agents who prefer the cheaper Turkish coal to Newcastle not only because of cheaper price but because it is nearer at hand for ships in Levant and Black Sea waters.

As regards shipping facilities, there are many. First of all the société runs severalsteamers to and from Zonguldagh, and besides this there are a number of Turkish steamers and sailing vessels which are continually bunkering or loading coal at the port. Most of the mines being on the sea the coal can be had as soon as possible, being delved, wasged and picked almost in sight of the steamers. The natural and artificial advantages of Zonguldagh are such that the ships can coal and clear without delay. The Zonguldagh valley is not the best coal of the Heraclea basin; there are other beds in the neighbouring valleys opening on to the sea which contain a rich seam of coal that is much appreciated. However as there is no port of shelter vessels have perforce to call at Zonguldagh and these include nearly all stemers engaged in the Black Sea trade.

There is a large field, as you lately pointed out, for the English capitalist in this region of Asio Minor. If the German is penetrating the interior, we might at least exploit the seacost of that naturally wealthy peninsula. Shipping agent.
Alexandria, July 9.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, JULY 9, 1906 page 5
SPEECH BY MR. CHURCHILL. ARMY REDUCTION. ATTACK ON THE LORDS.
div.p: London, July 8.

Mr. Churchill, speaking at Altrincham, said that the government was determined to effect the reductions in the army to which it had absolutley pledged itself. Mr. Haldane's statement of the 12th instant would show a substantial step in the path of military economy, without the dimunition of the forces necessary for national security. Referring to the attitude of the Lords on the Education Bill, he urged the necessity for the continuance of confidence in the Government in view of the possibility of collision with an unsound and irresponsible assembly that had ceased to fulfil its normal function.

div.head: THE DUMA. UTILISED AS REVOLUTIOARY CENTRE
div.p: St. Petursburg, July 7.

The Duma has rejected the Ministry's demand for 5,000,000, raiseable by a loan, for famine relief, and voted half a million only, declaring that the rest must be provided for by decreasing the budget expenditure.

General Trepoff, durig an interview, declared that the Duma is at present being utilised as a revolutionary centre, which cannot continue. He favoured the appointment of a Ministry composed of Dumas members only; this was a risky proceeding, but was urgent in order to pacify the country. (reuter)
Warsaw, July 8.
A Socialist proclamation calls upon the Polish Jews to arm themselves as the police are preparing a massacre.

div.head: THE BIELOSTOK MASSACRE GOVERNER RECALLED.
div.p: St. Petersburg 8.
The Governer of Grodno, against whom are serious allegations in connection with the Bielostok massacre, has been recalled. (reuter)

div.head: FRENCH NAVY SIX BATTLESHIPS TO BE BUILT.
div.p: Paris, July 7.
The Minister of Marine announces the intention of laying down six battleships at the end of this year, also the determination to keep the lead in the building of submarines. (reuter)

div.head: GREECE AND BULGARIA
div.p: Sofia, July 8.
The Bulgarians, despite a large force of police, refused to permit a Greek metropolitan to land Varna. (reuter)

div.head: ITALIAN NATIONAL DEBT.
div.p: Rome, July 7.
Chamber of Deputies- Sig. Giolitti congratulated himself on the result of the conversion of the National Debt.
Rome, July 8.
The Secratary of the Treasure announced that only a small fraction of the holders of Rente demanded reimbursements; the remainder is converted into stock (reuter).

div.head: KAISER AT TRONDHJEM
div.p: Trondhjem, July 8.
Emporor William has arrived. He was received by King Haakon. The two Sovereigns kissed each other.

div.head: REVISED RED CROSS CONVENTION
div.p: Geneva, June 7.

The revised Red Cross Convention was signed here yesterday. The Conference adopted the resolution to submit to the Hague Court disputed regarding the application of the Convention arising in time of peace, Great Britain, Japan, and Korea dissenting (reuter)

div.head: JAPANESE SHIP STRIKES MINE
div.p: Shanghai, July 7.
The Ningpo, bound for Japan, struck a mine 120 miles off the mouthe of the Yangtze Rover. The vessel has been damaged, but no lives were lost.

div.head: THE DREYFUS CASE.
div.p: Paris, July 7.
General Mercier has written to the President of the Court of Cassation, affirming Dreyfus's guilt. The Court will give its verdict on Tuesday or Wednesday.

div.head: NATAL REBELLION. GENERAL RISING CONSIDERED UNLIKELY
div.p: Durban, July 7.
The Government believe that the lsses inflicted on the natives will have a salutary effect, and a general rising is now regarded as unlikely. (reuter)
Durban, July 8.
Three columns surrounded Umvoti Gorge and elaboratley searched the almost impenetrable bush for Mesini, Bambaata's ancessor. They found the enemy gone.(reuter)

div.head: TRADE OF UNITED KINGDOM
div.p: London, July 7.
The importsduring June amounted to 17,892,709, being an increase of 4,335,305; the exports were 30,639,187, representing an increase of 4,653,790. (reuter)

div.head: "JOEY's" SEVENTIETH BIRTHDAY
div.p: Birmingham, July 7.
Great celebrations have been held here in honour of Mr. Chamberlain's 70th birthday. (reutur)

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: London, July 7.
Cricket. Hampshire beat somerset by 5 wickets. Surrey beat warwickshire by an innings and 63 runs. Derbyshire beat Sussex by 5 wichets. (reuter)

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY PROGRESS KAFUE BRIDGE OPENED
div.p: The "African World" has received a cable from Victoria Falls reporting the opening of the railway bridge ovr the Kafue River ofthe Cape to Cairo Railway, the first train having passed over. The bridge, which is the longest in South Africa, has been completed in the record period of five months. It consists of thirteen apane, ech 100 feet, with pillars resting on a bed 16 feet under the waater.

The Kafue River is 266 miles north of the Victoria Falls, and the distance from Cape Town is 1,908 miles. The railroad, howeer, is now at broken hill, 347 miles beyone the falls, the line having been pushed on simultaneously with the building of the bridge.

div.head: RAILWAY PROJECTS IN NIGERIA.
div.p: Sir Walter Egerton, High Commisioner for Southern Nigeria, has arrived in England in order, Reuter's agency understandably to confer with the Government in conjunction with Sir Frederick Lugard on thequestion of the contemplated extention of railways to the Niger, the improvement of Niger transports and other questions affecting cotton-growing, together with the extension of Lagos Harbour. His Excellency will reutn to Lagos on july 20.

In the matter of railway contriction the line from Lagos to Ibadan, a distance of 124 miles, is being prolonged to Oshogbo, 63 miles further in the interior, from which place another section of 60 miles will bring the line to Ilorin; and by a furhter extension of 56 miles the rails will reach the Niger at Jebbs. The moment the line touches the Niger at that place the trade of the Middle Niger will be open to all merchant firms in Lagos. At present extensive trade is impossible, except in the case of large capitalists, owing to the difficulties of communication, the waterway only being availabe for four months in the year, whereas with a line to theNiger all the Lagos firms will be able to establish branches on the river which can be placed in charge of juniors who can be easily supervised form LAgos. The unnoficial members of Council in Lagos have unanimously asked that the railway shall be extended at once to the Nier, a work for which theColony is prepared to raise a loan. It is estimated that 700,00 pounds will be required to complete the railway system of Southern Nigeria to the Niger at Jebbs. The Colony is prepared to do this without any appeal to Imperial Government. Ifthe railway is constructed by the Southern Nigerian Administration it was necessitate the rainsing of a further loan, but it is not expected in any case that this will be issued until next year.

Work on the railway extension is proceeding, and three month hene the firt section of 30 miles beynd Ibadan will be opened. A survey has also just been completed for a light railway connecting Sapele with Benin City.

It is expected that the first of a series of conferences between the Earl of Elgin and the High Communications for Northern and Southern Nigeria will take place next week. One important question to be settled is that of the point at which the projected railway shall touch the Niger. On this matter the consulting enginerrs favour Jebbs, while another project is to employ the waterway itself asfar upas the Lokojs, and thence to conrstuct a line fromthe confluence of the Niger and the Benue River to Kano. Another propsal will be that the terminus of the line shall be atBaro, a short distance above Kokojs, from which point ist would start to run inland.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.

div.head: ST. CATHERINES COLLEGE
div.p: The annual athletic sports of St. Catherine's College Alexandria, were held in the college playground on Thursday last and were in every way an unqualified success. The grounds were prettily decorated with garlands and flags, and some two to three thousand spectators were highly amused and interested until 7.30 p.m.The college band was in attendance and contributed several excellent pieces of music in a manner well worthy of the band's reputation.

The drilling excersices performed by some 250 boys with simultaneous movements were exceedingly well done and were greatly applauded. The gymnastic excercised were far above the average for boys so young; whether on the parallel or horizantal bar or on the rings the youngsters showed a smartness and an ability only attainable after considerable training. Mr. Arthur Sunas, the Gymnastic professor, is to be complimented on the very successful performances of his pupils, and also on the admirable manner in which he had trained the boys the pose in the pyramids, which were greatly appreciated. Among the notables present, we noticed Monseigneur Macaire, H.E. the Governnor, M. Pierre Girard, Consul-General for France, Saba Pacha, and Sciess Pachs.

The following is a list of the winners in the various sports. Special mention should be made of Mr.Nelson Schranz, who not only won the gold medal for gymnastics but also a bicycle presented by Count Ziginia forthe largest number of points scored. Some excellednt trick cycling was given to Mr. O. Giuliotti, and Messrs. Da Bono, Perdikis, Saunier, and Sitton where very amusing in the Comic interludes.

div.head: Commercial & financial supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The commercial and financial supplementofthe Egyptian Gazette is published at midday every saturday in time for the Sutrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics upto the evening of the proceeding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100(inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra) For further particulars apply to the manager "Egyptian Gazette"

div.head: Mount Troodos, Cyprus
div.p: A limited number of paying guests can be recieved by a Lady during the Summer Months. Cyprus is 24 hours by sea from Port Said. Troodos 6,406 feet above the sea is a delightful and healthy place amongst the pine forests where the stroops and Government Officials spend the hot season.
Terms 2 1/2 Guineas per week.
For furthur particluars apply to miss YOUNG, Mikosia, or to the Editor-
Furthur Particulars

Position. The pine covered slopes of Mount Troodos where Miss Young has a camp, are about 6,406 feet above the sea; the troops stationed in Cyrpus and the Principal Government Officials live there during the hot season from about June till October.

Routes. Troodos is about 35 miles from the port of Limassolfromwhich there is a good carriage road to Platres 31 m. Beyone Platres the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road from the Capital, Nicosia, by which persons going from that side of the Island drive all the way(about 16 miles.)
Climate. The climate is very dry and healthy; in the daytimes it is delightful; the nights, especially after the end of August are often rather cold.

Dress. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills, and ladies should be provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, but it is advisable to have some brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen dresses which do not show dirst stains as the washing is not first rate. A ward woolen "coat and skirt" costume is also indispensible
Rides. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are to steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hiredfor the season.
Expeditions. Places of interest to be reached on Mule or Pony back are Kykko Monastery, Kalopanaioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
Games. There is a tennis club wuth two good courts, there are alsoone or two private tennis and croquet grounds.
Church. An English Church Service is held twice on Sundays at the Regimental Recreation Room.
Water. The water supply is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome.
Money. Drafts on the Imperial Ottoman Bank and English Gold and notes accepted.
By June the railway which runs from the Famagusta to Nicosia will be extended to within 20 milesof Nikosia.
